            <gmd:abstract>
                <gco:CharacterString>Yellowknife Bay on Great Slave Lake is a water body of cultural, subsistence and recreational importance for the Yellowknives Dene First Nation and residents of Yellowknife. The ecosystem health of Yellowknife Bay has been impacted by historical mining releases of arsenic and metals, and contaminant loading to the bay from the closed Giant Mine continues today. Arsenic and metals were dispersed to the bay through atmospheric deposition of ore roaster emissions, as well as effluent and tailings releases at Giant Mine. Over several decades, considerable study has been conducted on arsenic and metal pollution in near- and far-field receiving environments of Yellowknife Bay. This three-year project aimed to enhance previous studies and investigate data gaps in order to obtain a more complete picture of the current environmental conditions in the bay. Multiple environmental components including water, sediment and the aquatic food chain were sampled to measure current levels of arsenic and metals, and to better understand the processes controlling their environmental fate. Project findings have been presented in several reports outlined below, and additional reports are being prepared to summarize the datasets. This project generated significant new information that will inform the management, assessment and use of the Yellowknife Bay ecosystem.</gco:CharacterString>
            </gmd:abstract>

name: 10-25976-48p4-st77
notes: Yellowknife Bay on Great Slave Lake is a water body of cultural, subsistence and recreational importance for the Yellowknives Dene First Nation and residents of Yellowknife. The ecosystem health of Yellowknife Bay has been impacted by historical mining releases of arsenic and metals, and contaminant loading to the bay from the closed Giant Mine continues today. Arsenic and metals were dispersed to the bay through atmospheric deposition of ore roaster emissions, as well as effluent and tailings releases at Giant Mine. Over several decades, considerable study has been conducted on arsenic and metal pollution in near- and far-field receiving environments of Yellowknife Bay. This three-year project aimed to enhance previous studies and investigate data gaps in order to obtain a more complete picture of the current environmental conditions in the bay. Multiple environmental components including water, sediment and the aquatic food chain were sampled to measure current levels of arsenic and metals, and to better understand the processes controlling their environmental fate. Project findings have been presented in several reports outlined below, and additional reports are being prepared to summarize the datasets. This project generated significant new information that will inform the management, assessment and use of the Yellowknife Bay ecosystem.

notes_translated.en: Yellowknife Bay on Great Slave Lake is a water body of cultural, subsistence and recreational importance for the Yellowknives Dene First Nation and residents of Yellowknife. The ecosystem health of Yellowknife Bay has been impacted by historical mining releases of arsenic and metals, and contaminant loading to the bay from the closed Giant Mine continues today. Arsenic and metals were dispersed to the bay through atmospheric deposition of ore roaster emissions, as well as effluent and tailings releases at Giant Mine. Over several decades, considerable study has been conducted on arsenic and metal pollution in near- and far-field receiving environments of Yellowknife Bay. This three-year project aimed to enhance previous studies and investigate data gaps in order to obtain a more complete picture of the current environmental conditions in the bay. Multiple environmental components including water, sediment and the aquatic food chain were sampled to measure current levels of arsenic and metals, and to better understand the processes controlling their environmental fate. Project findings have been presented in several reports outlined below, and additional reports are being prepared to summarize the datasets. This project generated significant new information that will inform the management, assessment and use of the Yellowknife Bay ecosystem.
notes_translated.fr: La baie de Yellowknife, sur le Grand lac des Esclaves, est un plan d'eau important pour la culture, la subsistance et les loisirs de la Première nation des Dénés de Yellowknife et des habitants de Yellowknife. La santé de l'écosystème de la baie de Yellowknife a été affectée par les rejets miniers historiques d'arsenic et de métaux, et le chargement de contaminants dans la baie par la mine Giant fermée se poursuit aujourd'hui. L'arsenic et les métaux ont été dispersés dans la baie par le dépôt atmosphérique d'émissions provenant des installations de torréfaction du minerai, ainsi que par les rejets d'effluents et de résidus à la mine Giant. Pendant plusieurs décennies, de nombreuses études ont été menées sur la pollution à l'arsenic et aux métaux dans les environnements récepteurs proches et éloignés de la baie de Yellowknife. Ce projet de trois ans visait à améliorer les études précédentes et à étudier les lacunes dans les données afin d'obtenir une image plus complète des conditions environnementales actuelles de la baie. De nombreux composants environnementaux, notamment l'eau, les sédiments et la chaîne alimentaire aquatique, ont été échantillonnés afin de mesurer les niveaux actuels d'arsenic et de métaux et de mieux comprendre les processus contrôlant leur devenir dans l'environnement. Les résultats du projet ont été présentés dans plusieurs rapports décrits ci-dessous, et des rapports supplémentaires sont en cours de préparation pour résumer les ensembles de données. Ce projet a généré de nouvelles informations importantes qui éclaireront la gestion, l'évaluation et l'utilisation de l'écosystème de la baie de Yellowknife.

notes_translation_method.fr: Description text translated using the Amazon translate service / texte traduit à l'aide du service Amazon translate

description_translated.en: DataStream is an open access platform for sharing water and sediment quality data.
description_translated.fr: DataStream est une plateforme en libre accès pour partager des données sur la qualité de l'eau et des sédiments.
